sub_topic: Finding the velocity and acceleration of an object using calculus
message_1: Suppose a car is moving along a straight line and its position at time t is given as s(t) = 3t^2 + 5t + 2 (in meters). Find the velocity and acceleration of the car at time t = 3 seconds, using calculus.
message_2:
To find the velocity of the car at time t, we need to find the first derivative of the position function s(t) with respect to time t. This will give us the velocity function v(t).

s(t) = 3t^2 + 5t + 2

Taking the first derivative with respect to t:

v(t) = ds/dt = 6t + 5

Now, to find the velocity at t = 3 seconds, we substitute t = 3 into the velocity function:

v(3) = 6(3) + 5 = 18 + 5 = 23

So, the velocity of the car at t = 3 seconds is 23 meters per second.

Next, to find the acceleration of the car at time t, we need to find the second derivative of the position function s(t) with respect to time t. This will give us the acceleration function a(t).

We already have the first derivative (velocity function) v(t) = 6t + 5. Now, we'll take the derivative of v(t) with respect to t:

a(t) = dv/dt = 6

The acceleration function a(t) is a constant, which means the acceleration is the same at any time t. Therefore, the acceleration of the car at t = 3 seconds is 6 meters per second squared.
